posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: With a new controller set for 2027, FTC and FRC will utilize RobotPython more extensively, especially with Blockly-generated code. A PDF from SystemCore discusses this further. Currently, my main contribution is solo, but I want to involve others. Several opportunities exist for proactive contributors. We welcome self-motivated individuals aiming to make an impact. Below are areas where assistance is needed: a VSCode Extension requiring TypeScript knowledge, improvements to the robotpy-installer project needing Python packaging skills, unit testing requiring test-writing abilities, robot tests involving PyTest expertise, and documentation needing writing ability. I regularly share potential projects on GitHub. Reviewing the repository might reveal opportunities for involvement.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Documentation - do you like writing? My availability will be a bit up and down over the next 12 months or so, but if you find a larger bucket of work that needs thought about, feel free to @ me in an issue and I can start discussion of how to break it down and tackle it.

posts.name: Adam Gaddis
posts.cooked: For the 2027 controller I expect that we’ll probably move to deploying to a virtualenv

posts.name: Adam Gaddis
posts.cooked: We are going to transition to using robotpy this next season, so I would be more than happy to assist wherever I can. I believe I can participate in the robotpy-installer process and support documentation or testing efforts.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: For installer work there are lots of issues on github and the 2027 specific updates can be discussed at issue 143

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Especially as SystemCore dates approach, I’d be happy to help here, if nothing else out of a sense of self-preservation. With documentation, there’s two large buckets of work: Examples, examples, examples—there’s still lots of documentation pages that only have Java/C++ examples. Installation documentation is fine, but there are still questions on CD about Chief Delphi about it, so it can be better. Probably some improvement is needed here, but what those improvements are is rather ill-defined.
How opposed are you to a PyCharm plugin? I'm unsure how a VSCode extension would function in this scenario, though it could potentially be developed similarly to @Javaru's InteliJ plugin.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
Getting started with Python on a new team feels overwhelming, but there's plenty I can do to help. I should probably start by reviewing some basics before jumping in. Asking for guidance is something I need to think about too—I wonder how best to approach my team members. Maybe beginning with simple questions is a good idea.

Identifying tasks that match my current skills versus those requiring further learning is crucial. Clear communication will ensure everyone knows my contributions. Introducing myself to colleagues and showing interest in their work could lead to collaboration opportunities.

Setting clear, achievable goals for the next few weeks seems smart. Tracking progress will help me stay focused without feeling overwhelmed. Taking it one step at a time and proactively seeking information will aid my smooth integration into the team.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: An eventual goal could be to integrate with the existing WPILib VSCode extension, which might provide greater impact than a PyCharm extension. Either option would require someone to implement it, though I am supportive of creating a tool like this.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: cake deer6 says: i just graduated off a new-to-python team and i’d love to start helping. getting started seems pretty daunting. any advice or anything i should know ahead of time? generally, you’ll be more productive if you’re doing something you find interesting and can put your head around. trying to fix things that personally annoy you can be a good motivator too.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: To add onto this, we are planning to host VS Code on the controller in 2027 for on-controller development, and extensions that provide command-line-free operation for creating and deploying Python robot code would be beneficial for both on-robot and desktop use cases.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked: I realize that bootstrapping a RobotPy project with UV can be done, but I don't think it's something I'd want to introduce to a new user. On reflection, I prefer the method where you use `uv init robotpy-example`, then navigate to your project folder and run `uv add robotpy`. Following that, executing a series of commands—moving `pyproject.toml`, running `uv` to initialize, copying the updated configuration back, and cleaning up—the process creates a consistent environment for development. While I understand there's room for improvement, I wish the setup were even simpler.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: I was thinking about UV being useful in the context of the installer deploying to the robot (which the installer has full control over so simplicity isn’t as important) to replace pip (primarily for speed reasons).

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked: I am not well versed in the entire universe of Python package managers, but uv has not ticked me off yet, and that is saying something. I am thinking of this mostly because I am wondering what a VSCode extension would do. My first thought is bootstrapping a project. Adding in a vendordep manager, which in the Python case is simply a pyproject.toml modification. Although, in that case, the default of placing them there and allowing users to uncomment them is quite friendly to me. For something you're coding up. And lets you pin versions once you know the syntax. Why not offer an option to enable serious linting and type checking? Just thinking out loud. Don’t read too much into my ramblings.

posts.name: Adam Gaddis
posts.cooked:
Yeah, it’s easier to just do robotpy init first and then copy the project section from the top of pyproject.toml because uv only needs that. So run uvx robotpy init which avoids installing robotpy altogether. Then robotpy init just needs to add a [project] section in pyproject.toml. Currently, it only has [tool.robotpy]. Uv doesn’t need access to pyproject.toml, just requires it to have a [project] section. Once you add the basic project section, you can use uv freely. My exact steps were:

1. Run uvx robotpy init
2. Edit pyproject.toml and add basic project section

[project]
name = "quick-test"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Add your description here"
readme = "README.md"
requires-python = ">3.13"
dependencies = []

Then run uv add robotpy and everything works nicely.

posts.name: Joey R
posts.cooked: I wouldn’t worry too much about documentation, you can use DeepWiki, which crawls your repository and generates documentation that rates between 6-7/10, though it’s a great starting point to build upon. Additionally, the AI-RAG or whatever is currently being used works nicely as well. It’s particularly effective for monorepos, such as those found in WPILib or Python code, where it shines due to obvious reasons.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked:
Installer improvements - do you know Python packaging? The robotpy-installer project has a lot of open usability improvement bugs that would be great for someone to work on. For the 2027 controller, I expect we'll probably move to deploying to a virtualenv—how that works is still unclear, and you could help shape it.

I’ve created troll programs to disrupt people’s computers and have extensively used Python packaging and software deployment across different devices. I’m willing to contribute my time to assist with this project.

I haven’t worked with Robotpy yet, but I believe I can learn it effectively to support the team.

posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: I have made a VSCode extension for robotpy already. Currently, it simply sends commands to the terminal when a button is clicked from the sidebar. However, I am willing to enhance it further.

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: Everything I’ve seen from deepwiki has been pretty poor, and I believe this could be worsened by the fact that robotpy wraps a ton of C++ code using its own unconventional system. It’s no better than bad documentation.

Unit Testing - do you like breaking things on purpose? There are lots of tests in allwpilib, and very few tests in mostrobotpy. Everything probably works, but if you help us write tests we can catch more problems before they reach teams. I’d be happy to take a look and implement some geometry unit tests once these darn AP exams finish.

data.title: RobotPy looking for a few good contributors
data.fancy_title: RobotPy looking for a few good contributors
